ResponsesInList.Title: Workshop decluttering for students - thoughts & feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: I've spent some time listening to feedback from staff about Workshop -- there's so much 'stuff' there that it needs a lot of decluttering. I'm posting what I've done so far, and invite feedback or ideas on what you may have done or thought about doing. Phase 1: Setup I hate to have done this, but we decided to hide the details of each phase. Though it contains important information and useful, we've decided to hide it entirely so the students just see the phase they are on and can rely on the existing "Description" area to get all the info they need to start (though it doesn't remain there as the phases progress). We also debated showing all 4 dates (both open and both close) but decided the 2 "close" is the more important dates to show. Phase 2: Submission We moved the " Add Submission " button down below the Your Submission section to help better connect the two things. Once a student submits, their name was clickable - we removed that hyperlink so the only important link is a link back to their submission. We're debating if we want to break the links for the two toggle sections ... Phase 3: Assessment Here's where I got overwhelmed and not sure of the best approach. By default, there are 8 different links a student can click on when the Assessment phase begins. My goal is to only have 2 clickable links. So far, I have removed the 2 links  for the student's "Name" in the image below. 3 links are actually Toggles. My plan is to make the Toggles black, hide the icon, and give it a pointer-event of "None" so they cannot close it, I just don't know if that will make issues with keyboard navigation. Then that would leave 3 more links - the submission file name, the assigned assessment file name, and the Assess button. My next though is to guide the student to that Assess button by breaking the link to the assigned assignment file name, but I don't know what the difference is between the file title and the button. My guess is after they provide their assessment, maybe that file name link is their only way back to see their the assessment they provided. Interested in thoughts or if you have done anything similar you wish to share. Thanks,

ResponsesInList.Title: Understanding the grading for Workshop activity
ResponsesInList.Text: Gotcha! First, by default the total score for submission of an assignment is 80, and assessment of other students is 20. This can be adjusted in settings. How is the submission score calculated? If Person A assesses a submission with a score of 50/100, the score is calculated as 50 * 0.8 = 40 points. In other words 80% of 50 = 40 points. If Person B gives a score of 75/100, the score would be 60 points. If those are the only two scores, the average is 50 points, resulting in a submission score of 50/80. That's the simple answer. Weighting of individual scores adds another element, but I won't go into it unless you'd like to hear about it. How is the assessment score calculated? This is how well (accurate and fair) the student assessed a given submission. How is this determined, you may ask. If a student’s grading is very close to the group average, they get a higher assessment grade. If their grading is very different, their assessment grade is lower. The teacher can then adjust how strictly this can be enforced via the Comparison of Assessments dropdown menu (very lax - very strict). The total score for this is 20 by default. That's the simple answer. Once again, weighting and overriding of scores are additional factors.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Export Workshop activity submissions and assessments
ResponsesInList.Text: As far as I know, there is no way to download all Workshop submissions at once.  In my opinion, this is a major flaw of this activity type. As a possible workaround, I have used the following procedure: Create a "Student folder" activity, setting Required Teacher approval and Automatic Student approval in "Publication settings". Setup the Workshop activity to accept only "online text" in the submission types. Instruct students to submit work on the student folder, copy the link to their submission there, and paste it as their submission on the workshop activity.  They only submit text (the link) on the workshop. When submission phase ends, press the "Give approval" button on the Student folder activity, to publish all submissions.  This makes them accessible to all students.  Also, move the Workshop to Assessment phase. On the workshop assessment instructions, tell students to follow the links their peers submitted in order to download their work. Then assess as usual. The student folder activity is similar to assignment activity, but also allows publishing of the submissions to all users.  Unlike workshop It allows downloading all submissions easily. This scheme is somewhat complex and this will lead to misinterpretation and human error.  A few students will submit on the student folder and forget to submit on the workshop.  Or they'll paste an invalid link, such as as link to a personal cloud folder, on the workshop. Hope this helps.

ResponsesInList.Title: Per submission vs Per reviewer in workshop random allocation
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear community, first of all, thank you very much for your excellent work and extraordinary educational tool. I have a question about the difference between "per submission" and "per reviewer" of the random allocation option of Workshop. I have looked for some information, and the potentially closest discussion is in this link: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=216305#p942023 Unfortunately, I have not been able to ask my question there. The thing is that, to my understanding, it should be possible, and not very difficult, to make the random allocator to assign as many reviewers per submission as submissions per reviewer; so, if students that did not submit their work are not allowed to review other submissions, the option X reviews per submission or per reviewer could be ignored. My idea is to generate X (from "X reviewes per...") permutations of the submissions (easy with the numpy library, for instance). Then, for each permutation, reviewers are assigned to the submissions according to the generated permutation. Since the number of submissions is equal to the number of reviewers, because just submitters are allowed to review, and permutations are bijective functions, each submission is assigned to one reviewer and each reviewer is associated to one submission. This procedure is repeated for the X-1 remaining permutations. There is still a possibility of assigning the same submission more than once to the same reviewer, or even a submission to its submitter. However, with enough submissions (and thus, reviewers), I think that this is not very probable and the random allocator could replace problematic permutations with new randomly generated ones (within a while loop and a maximum number of draws). In case non-submitters were allowed to review, then this solution should be fixed, but in any case, you could use your current allocator in this case. That is all. I just wanted to share this possibility with you. My apologies in case I had missed any relevant piece of information that makes my solution invalid. Best wishes!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Scheduled allocation set to 3 but Moodle allocated 6
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ulrike, Yes, we have and had worst cases than that (imagine 21 allocations per submission instead of 3). It is an issue of slow performance in your site most likely. If the performance is bad, and the allocations are many, your system might start the process and restart it again if it doesn't end in time. Therefore duplicating the number of allocations. The solution is to go manually inside the workshop in a time the system is not so overloaded and rerun manually the allocation process again while clicking on the "remove current allocations".

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Workshop's grading is weird
ResponsesInList.Text: Frankly, I never looked in to the maths behind the "grade for assessment". I paraphrase few things from that page to my people, so that they take assessment seriously. In essence, closer you are to the mean, better your grade will be. If your people love maths this para is a good starting point: The workshop picks one of the assessments as the best one - that is closest to the mean of all assessments - and gives it a grade of 100%. Then it measures the 'distance' of all other assessments from this best one and gives them lower grades depending on how different they are from the best assessment (given that the best one represents a consensus of the majority of assessors). The parameter of the calculation is how strict we should be, that is how quickly the grades fall down if they differ from the best one. Or if they are more attracted to voodoo, this would suffice: This grade (also known as grading grade) is calculated by the artificial intelligence hidden within the Workshop module... More seriously, https://docs.moodle.org/en/Using_Workshop#See_also has a link to " Moodle Workshop activities support peer review in Year 1 Science: present and future by Julian M Cox, John Paul Posada and Russell Waldron", which is broken. A random web search brought this instead: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Russell-Waldron-2/publication/251875400_Moodle_Workshop_activities_support_peer_review_Year_1_Science_present_and_future/links/0c96051f1a41a8913a000000/Moodle-Workshop-activities-support-peer-review-Year-1-Science-present-and-future.pdf . ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am attaching a screencast of the error (mp4, 2 MB). I have a workshop where a student can use the rubric to evaluate his own work as well. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: error: override for assessment -> no change of grade
ResponsesInList.Text: No, it's not a bug. Students in workshops get two grades. One is "Grade for submission" based on received evaluations of their own work. The second is "Grade for assessment" based on the provided evaluations of others' work. Your student in the video received grade for submission 7.1 out of 10, based on their own self-evaluation. And she/he received grade for assessment 5.0 out of 5.0. What you overrode is that second grade. To affect both grades you as a teacher better go and provide your own evaluation of their work (using the same evaluation form). In this particular case, you will probably want to fill all rubric fields with lowest quality descriptions. And you will also want to set higher weight of your own assessment. That way, your assessment will have much bigger impact on both grades calculations. Yet another option to override the grades calculated by the module is in the course gradebook.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How display Workshop description during Submission phase?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jim, The behavior you see is expected, as it is the way the workshop code is written. If your REALLY want to show the description during the submission phase, you will need to copy some code from the, case workshop::PHASE_SETUP: and then add it into the case workshop::PHASE_SUBMISSION:. Of course, if you do this, you will need to remember to do it any time there is an update to the Workshop activity plugin. Assuming you are using Moodle 3.7.2+ with Workshop version 2019052000, open the workshop/view.php file. Assuming line 110 is:  case workshop::PHASE_SETUP: Copy lines 111-115 Assuming line 137 is: case workshop::PHASE_SUBMISSION: Paste your copied lines in as 138-142. Save the file and go to submission phase of your activity and you should see the, Description, added right above the, Instructions for submission. NOTE: Doing it this way permanently adds the Description to the Submission phase of EVERY Workshop you have on your whole site. It DOES NOT appear/disappear by changing the checkmark used to display it on the course page.

ResponsesInList.Text: The class follows a writing process: They submit prewriting in an assignment module. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Block a Certain Student from Submitting
ResponsesInList.Text: We do this with restrict access, as David mentioned. In the Assignment module, edit settings > restrict access > Student Must match the following > Activity completion Assignment X must be marked complete. Turn on Activity completion at the site level. At the Course level > Edit settings > Completion Tracking > Enable completion tracking > Yes. For Each Assignment, Edit Settings > Completion Tracking > Show activity as complete when conditions are met > Require grade > Student must receive a grade to complete this activity Then you want to fiddle with grading to decide what's passing, etc. Note that Completion only requires A grade, not a PASSING grade.

ResponsesInList.Title: Increased Student Confidence and Quality of Team-Based Presentations
ResponsesInList.Text: Thought I would share our Peer Assessment (Workshop module) experiences surrounding a project we carried out with team-based Vet Nursing students with their practical public presentations, which is related to the post I had made earlier: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=352404 As part of SQA's (Scottish Qualification Authority) HNC Vet Nursing Graded Unit 1 assessment, the Vet Nursing students within their teams are required to plan, develop and deliver an educational presentation that is designed to promote the importance of animal health and welfare to the public. During analysis of the practical presentation element, research was carried out with previous HNC Vet Nursing students and had found the lack of communication, collaboration, team dynamics, and the fear of presenting publicly, where is some cases lowering the student's individual grades. Therefore, we had the idea of digitally video recording the six Graded Unit teams 'prototype' presentations, uploading to the team's YouTube channel as Unlisted and having an allocated student member within their team submit to the Workshop module within Moodle. Working collaboratively and using the guidelines and criterion set within the workshop module, a student (who originally submitted their team's video presentation) accessed their allocated Graded Unit team's video presentation will all team members present providing supportive feedback and constructive criticism within the Workshop activity. See screenshots below. The lecturer analysed the team’s peer review feedback and reinforced the peer reviewer’s valuable guidance. Once the feedback was released to the teams and within their Moodle discussion forums, the teams quickly advanced in self-assessing their own presentation performance utilising the criterion and favourably integrating the recommendations within their regular rehearsals leading up to their public presentations. The peer assessment phase considerably increased the student’s confidence and the quality of their public presentations where 30 out of the 36 students received an A-grade for their individual presentation performance. Positive feedback from the students included: “The peer feedback gave me an extra boost to my confidence and due to this, when I actually carried out the presentation on the day, I felt quite calm.” A full online report on the project will be available in July.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Rename Workshop to Peer Assessment?
ResponsesInList.Text: Derek, Thanks for listing those four things, which I deem the expected consequences. Another expected consequence will be the loss of the rich history of the Workshop as a method of teaching writing. The Workshop method of teaching writing is an outgrowth of the work of Donald Murray and many others. Murray did the most writing about the process, but that process or workshop method has been used by many others before and after Murray, including my mentor Frederick Manfred . The Workshop method/process is a revered staple of T he Loft and many other writing schools and guilds. One of the most famous is the University of Iowa's Writers Workshop. The concept of a writer's workshop includes peer assessment, but the term peer assessment does not include workshop. In other words, Workshop is a bigger, richer, more inclusive term than peer assessment. There will be other unintended and unnecessary consequences by changing the name of this very powerful Moodle tool, too. The biggest problem with the Workshop Module is its complexity. We still don't have enough written about how to use it in all of the possible ways that it can be used. I'd rather spend our collective energy on making the wonders of the Workshop Module more accessible to more teachers and students. I'm not convinced calling it Peer Assessment will actually make it better understood and more  accessible.

ResponsesInList.Title: Encouraging real assessment and comments.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, My wife and I are lecturers in a Chinese university and have found that academic dishonesty runs rampant here at times. Students often do not read that which they were assigned to assess, and rarely give long enough useful comments. They just auto mark with a high grade and move on without doing any real assessment at all. The current grading method actually seems to allow assessors to do this, as they are not punished for short comments or dishonest grading practices. Are there any improvement plugins or can I somehow for comment length (or grade them for it?) Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Encouraging real assessment and comments.
ResponsesInList.Text: That's an interesting discussion topic - as I think it is actually related more to pedagogy and overall attitude to education, rather than particular software feature implementation. What I mean is, I personally think these things must be really communicated well with the students. They must understand what is expected from them - and why it is expected. That is what example submissions and assessments were supposed to be used for - to show examples of a good assessment and examples of a bad/insufficient assessment. How does it help to have a minimum required length for comments if students do not really feel like motivated to provide meaningful feedback? There is nothing that will prevent them to fill it with non-sense ballast to make the stupid system happy. Life - and laziness - finds a way. Technically it is possible to implement these things (comments required or minimum length required etc). But what is really broken here?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Encouraging real assessment and comments.
ResponsesInList.Text: I appreciate your opinion, but it does appear you've never taught in China. It is a different animal here entirely, and your focus is through the lens of a Western academician. Any Chinese educator would reply in a different way. The question of academic dishonesty, as well as the virtues of education itself, are seen quite differently here. I am not in a position to change a culture, and that is what you are asking me to do. This may seem like I am painting with a broad brush, but that truly isn't the case. Even the best students would be too afraid to give others low marks, as it costs them "face". The weaker students are simply there before they know the Chinese education system requires presence, not participation and will only do what is "hard coded and tangibly required" in order to squeak by. That means more than half of the class will only give two word comments. I'm not going to get in to the post-maoist refugee syndrome of every man for himself that is present here enlarge, but I will say that no amount of communication will convince more than half the class to leave reasonable criticism without some reward/punishment system in place. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Reporting/logs on Workshop activity missing for student action

if he was able to download the documents without Moodle having a log for it I just checked the code and it can easily happen actually. There is an event logged for every time when a particular submission is displayed via the submission.php script (that is clicking the submission title). Such an event is then logged as "Submission viewed": 
```text
The user with id 'X' viewed the submission with id 'Y' for the workshop with course module id 'Z'.
```
 But, during the assessment phase, students typically end on the assessment.php page where the very same submission is displayed as well - together with the attachments - without leaving the event logged. That is a bug and it will help if you can report it in the Moodle Tracker . So yes, the student could read the submission and download the attachment. However, if the student provided the assessment via the workshop interface (that is, if he actually filled and submitted the assessment form), there would be another event "Submission assessed" logged: 
```text
The user with id 'X' assessed the submission with id 'Y' for the user with id 'Z' in the workshop with course module id 'W'.
```
 So maybe the student just did not understand that he was supposed to actually fill the assessment form via the web and submit it? (assuming the Workshop was really used like this). Generally, let me discourage you from making any decision based on the absence of the event in Moodle logs (not only in Workshop).

ResponsesInList.Title: Overriding grade of submission and assessment
ResponsesInList.Text: I am wondering if there is a pedagogical reasoning behind the following observation related to overriding submission/assessment scores: Moodle computes the "Grade for assessment" by averaging individual grades. It is possible to override one or more assessment scores individually . I n regards to “Grade for submission”, Moodle does not allow to override the scores individually . Only option is to override the final score. So these two functionalities (computing grade for assessment vs submission) are in odds with each other.  I would have really liked the ability to just override one of the received grades (for computing the grade of submission) but Moodle does not allow that!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Overriding grade of submission and assessment
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Gurman for opening this topic. Let me try and explain the reasoning for the current behaviour (I am the author of the Workshop 2.x code). As a teacher, you have several options to affect the grades given to students in the Workshop (in their role both as authors and as peer-reviewers). You can provide your own assessment, eventually with higher weight than peers have, so it will have bigger impact on the calculations. Your assessment is considered as another peer-assessment so it affects both the assessed submission's grade, and also the assessment grades of all others who assessed the submission, too. You can override the final grade for each submission, e.g. because you are the only one who know about some author's disabilities that led to receiving lower grade. So even if you accept all the peer-assessments, you still want to set the different grade. This way, you amend just the submission's grade without affecting reviewers' assessment grades. You can override the individual grade for assessment. That is the grade that is calculated by the grading evaluation plugin in use. The typical use case is when reviewers get lower grades from the "comparison with the best assessment" evaluation method just because their review is not "in line" with all others assessments of the same submission. Yet you realize that even if the reviewer was sole in their assessment, they were actually right. Maybe they were the only one who spotted a mistake or so. So you want to fix this particular mis-calculation. As a last resort, you can still override both final grades for submission and grade for assessment for each student in the gradebook once the grade is pushed there (which currently happens only when you are closing the workshop, this will be improved in the future). My reasoning was that when teachers are overriding a grade in the Workshop, they should have particular reason for that. So they re-grade particular submission (because this and that in this submission is good/wrong), or particular assessment (because this and that in this assessment is good/wrong). There should be a clear evidence that a particular grade has been overridden and for what reason. What you would like to have is the ability to override the submission grade coming from a single reviewer. But that grade is calculated by the selected grading strategy and is based on how the assessment form (e.g. rubric) has been filled. Imagine there are three reviewers of a submission. They all fill the assessment form (say a rubric) same. I believe it is reasonable to expect that same filled rubric should lead to same grade. Why would you want to override one of it? In my mind, it just goes against the whole idea of using multi-criterial assessment forms to achieve more objective assessment. That is what led me to implementing the current behaviour. I generally love the feedback from teachers working with the Workshop and I'll be happy to hear your use-cases / reasoning for your feature request. Thanks in advance!

This student's grade is reported as 10/12, but when you add up the points awarded, they add to 11. In my mind: 6+4+1 = 11, not 10. Any suggestions? I have attached a graphic file. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assessors Grade not Calculating Properly
ResponsesInList.Text: I forgot to add that this is not happening to all students, just a few. Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assessors Grade not Calculating Properly
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Caryl. It is not calculated like that. Please refer to https://docs.moodle.org/en/Workshop_grading_strategies#Accumulative_grading_strategy for full details. In this particular case, the actual calculation is `(6/6 + 4/4 + 1/2) / 3 * 12 = 10.0` Shortly, in the accumulative grading strategy, it does not matter if the max grade for the aspect is 6, 4 or 2. If you want to make some of them more important, increase their weights. I agree this may look counter-intuitive at the first sight. But it is the only way how to make it possible to use scales and grades in one assessment form.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can allocate

ResponsesInList.Title: OU Workshop requests: Usability
ResponsesInList.Text:
This thread follows on (after a rather longer deplay than I was expecting) from https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=283014 We have a number of small requests around usability , or rather, we have a list of things we know some users struggled with. We don't necessarily have solutions. Ability to add information/instructions 'Overall assessment' There is an option 'Overal feedback mode' that gives the
student to box in which to type and overall comment, after completing the rest of the grading form. However, there is no way to give instructions next to that box, like
there is for the other aspects of the grading method. Inconsistent editors when assessing On the assessment form, the input box for each of the Apsects is a plain textarea, but the input for the 'Overall assessment' is a HTML editor. I think we would like them to all be HTML editors. Students get confused by the intructions when reviewing their submission Even after the end of the submission phase, when a student reviews their submission (e.g. http://school.demo.moodle.net/mod/workshop/submission.php?cmid=651&id=48 ) the "Instructions for submission" are shown first, and are often written imperatively ("Write three sentences ..."). Apparently some students got confused by this, because when you are reviewing, you can't do that! I wonder if a solution to this is as simple as collapsing the instructions for submission by default when reviewing. (They are already in a collapsible region.) The link to review a submission is not easy to find The link to review your own submission is just the title of that submission. This was not obvious to all students. It might be better to change it to be a separate 'Review submission' link. Save and continue does not work well with requried fields The assessment form has a 'Save and continue editing' button. Students assuemd they could use this to stop half way through assessing, and come back later. However, since all the fields on the assessment form are required, you can't acutally do that. You have to fill in all the boxes (if only with junk) before you can save. If you do fill all the boxes with junk, you have not way of being reminded that you have not actually finished assessing. The ability to save partially complete assessments, to finish later, would be good (but a pain to implement). Option to display reviews by aspect, not reviewer At the moment, you see the review given by each user, and
for each user, and each review comments on a number of aspects. In this case it
would be good if there was the option to have the display grouped by aspect, and under each aspect, you
saw all the comments from each reviewer.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Workshop submission scores include "0" grades from students that don't complete assessment phase
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Bryan. Thanks for reporting this issue. Can you provide more details on what grading strategy was used in this workshop? It sounds weird to me. When students do not provide the assessment - meaning that they did not attempt to assess it at all - the screenshot should show the received grade like "- (-)" - that is null, no grade. In which case, such assessment would be ignored.
If the "0.0" is there, it means that students actually did assess the submission. But I agree that leaving the assessment form untouched should not lead to zero grade received. If that is what happens, then we have an usability bug here.
To fix this situation for now, you can either remove those allocated assessments (via the manual allocation tool) or set the weight of such assessments to 0 which effectively ignores them then.

ResponsesInList.Title: Workshop accessibility issues
ResponsesInList.Text: We have been trialling using the Workshop module at the Open University. As a results of this we have a list of changes we think would be a good idea, or at least that we would like to discuss. I will probably post about then in a few separate threads, where I will group the changes by topic. If people agree with our proposals, I will make tracker issues for them. This first set should be relatively un-controversial. There are some accessibility issues we have spotted: The current phase is only indicated by hilighting one row in the table. You cannot show something with colour alone. Therefore, there needs to be some extra text to indicate the current Phase, possibly with class="accesshide". Alternatively, MDL-44010 might be a solution, but I don't think so. We are using the "Comments" grading method, but this probably applies to "Accumulative" too, and perhaps some others. When students are grading, the description of each aspect is not properly linked to the corresponding input box using <label> tags, or aria-labelledby, so screen-reader users find it difficult to complete the grading form. Various parts of the interface had insufficient contrast , which would make it hard for partially sighted users. We should tweak the CSS to increase the contrast. (Actually, I think this issue related to the file-picker, not the Workshop.) Any objections before I make tracker issue for these?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Workshop accessibility issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim firstly, big thanks to your and the whole OU team who have been working on Workshop evaluation. You initiative is very welcome here. The points 2. and 3. above are clear bugs and should be fixed. I'll be happy to discuss with your accessibility experts and follow their suggestions on this. With regards to the point 1., it indeed is a clear bug too. I've had a plan to replace the current "workshop planner" (the table with phases) for a long time but did not manage to find time for it yet. The current solution has multiple issues - most notably for mobile and small screen devices. Firstly, setting that widget's width to less than 100% all the time is suboptimal. It is not responsive. And overall, it is a table which it should not be. If we agree that displaying a "wizard-like" element that displays all the past, current and future tasks the user is going through in the workshop, I would really like to reimplement it into more appropriate HTML structure (list, or maybe definition list) and style it as horizontally aligned blocks. In any case, the current phase (or just the current individual's state in the future) will have to be clearly identified from the accessibility point of view. So, definitely my +10 on all these.

ResponsesInList.Title: Switching into different phase automatically
ResponsesInList.Text: It doesn't appear that workshop switches into the different phases automatically. Is it something I am doing or is it a missing feature. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Switching into different phase automatically
ResponsesInList.Text: Can we fix that ASAP? No. There is nothing to fix as this is not a bug but an intentional feature. Many problems in Workshop 1.x were there just because Workshop did a lot of things silently in the background. So it was decided and described in the Workshop 2.0 specification document that the new version would be interactive and would require more user input - thus allowing total control over what is going on. Bad things might happen if - for example - some student were not given a submission to assess. The workshop activity would continue with this student left behind and no-one would spot anything wrong. So there must always be a human who confirms that the workshop can continue to the next phase. I am sorry you find the fact that you must pay attention to the workshop "cumbersone, akward and time-consuming". But Workshop 2.0 was not designed as a stand-alone tool looking after everything.

ResponsesInList.Title: Allowing overlapping phases: discussion and suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: In this issue: MDL-27238 the suggestion is made to allow more flexibility of which phase students are in. David has suggested: What is doable is to introduce a new phase covering both submission and assessment phase. I still resist to allow any on-the-fly calculation of the final grades because they rely on all submissions are available. Still, there are many open questions that must be answered prior any actual development can start. Most notably: How should submissions allocation behave? I can imagine a new allocator type ("instant" for example) that would automatically allocate the submission immediately after it is saved and marked as final by the student. Note this automatically enforces that a submission can be reviewed by a student that has not submitted anything yet (otherwise, the first submission could not get any reviewer). How to improve the submission workflow and keep it still easy to understand for students. The author has to mark (tag) the submission as "ready for assessment". But then, maybe on the initial feedback from the reviewers, the student has to have an option to switch the status back to "work in progress" (when no other assessment is possible) and then submit it for assessment again. Do we expect that the submission is re-allocated in this case? In other words, I believe it is possible to allow submission + assessment phase overlapping. But to calculate the grades, both submitting and assessing must be finished. Most significantly, the allocation of submissions seems to be a tricky one: When the first student submits their work, there is nothing else to be allocated to them for assessment. When the second student submits their work, there is only one work to be allocated. Should it be allocated or not? Students might easily abuse this behaviour to "choose" their own reviewer, instead of having them assigned randomly. As other students are submitting their work, the pool of submission is getting bigger and bigger and the allocation may seem to work. Still we have pretty unbalanced situation as early submissions are already assigned for assessments and hence are unlikely to be assessed by students who submit their own work later. At the end of this time scale there is another problem emerging. The very last submission must be allocated to someone. But by that time those students may think that their task was already done. In other words, students never know if there is some submission to be allocated for them yet or not. Until the phase is closed, they never know the expected amount of work to do ("Mr Boerman, I already did all assigned peer-reviews last week. I did not know that a new submission can appear"). I will follow with a post with my suggestions. David asks that we work through these issues in this forum to make sure the needs of the community are taken into account.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Allowing overlapping phases: discussion and suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: Here are some of my suggestions regarding David's questions: As David suggests, set a lower limit for starting the review allocation process. For example, require at least 3 submissions before allocating any reviewers. Prior to that point, display "Insufficient submissions to start allocation process" to students, instead of a grade. This deals with several points of concern that David raised. This limit should not affect self-assessment, which should take place immediately upon submission, with an opportunity for the student to update their own work before allocation to others. If students are going to self-assess, it should be done as quickly as possible so they can have the material fresh in their minds, and they should be able to correct errors before letting the process go further. I would be reluctant to allow the student to continue to revise between this point and the completion of the required number of peer reviews. An option to restrict allocation to those students who have been given a grade of at least n for that assignment would be helpful. The instructor would assess the first couple of students, then they would be able to assess others. This allows a "snowball" effect of more and more potential assessors. This addresses another of David's key points. Yes, later submitters will be allocated to other later submitters for assessment, but the assessors are validated in this process, so there should be less of an impact on the quality of assessment. Set a lower limit of number of peer assessments before displaying a grade. If there have not been enough peer reviews yet, display "grading incomplete" or similar message to the student, rather than a grade for the assignment. Obviously, this number could be set to 0 for teacher-only assessments or 1 if the student should be able to see partial grades. Set the number of required assessments per student, and display to each student the number of assessments they have completed whenever they check the Workshop (or even better, in the student view after the link to the workshop). Allow the instructor to set a due date after which no more student assessments will be allocated (the instructor will have to decide whether to assess stragglers at that point). This addresses David's last point. Finally, there is an ongoing discussion of how to handle resubmissions within the Assignment module [ MDL-36804 ]. Ultimately, I think it would be helpful to merge Assignment and Workshop modules, but in the meantime, some kind of audit trail of submissions needs to be maintained, and possibly multiple rounds of resubmission and peer review should be supported in Workshop, with an instructor option to maintain reviewers in consistent groups (probably using the Groups feature) or re-allocating in each round of revisions. This is consistent with supporting good writing process by encouraging multiple drafts of major works with review and revision between each draft (i.e. what I usually think of as the "workshop" process.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Allowing overlapping phases: discussion and suggestions
ResponsesInList.Text: I have very strong feelings about this and have proposed different solutions from time to time. I am experimenting with a peer review tool called SWoRD out of University of Pittsburgh. They have a feature called soft deadlines. The way it works is you set the submission due date in the past. When a student submits a paper, the system then allows them to request a paper to review. There is an algorithm that selects the paper that has been waiting longest with the fewest number of reviewers. After one review is complete, the reviewer can then request more papers to review. In my dream world, this is how workshop would work. Rather than being driven by dates, it could be driven by events. Event one: paper submission Result: student can request papers to review (if none are available, or if there are too few in the system to prevent collusion or ensure anonymity, the user may need to come back later) Event two: the student has reviewed all required papers and their paper has been reviewed the required number of times Result: a grade is generated Some possible ideas additional ideas include: Allow people to request additional papers to review for extra experience, and possibly extra points This could help ameliorate the problem of some students not doing their reviews Dates could still play a role as a soft "best if done by" deadline to help keep the class on roughly the same pace I would assign a small amount of bonus or penalty point for doing the assignment early or late, but let the students manage their own time. The interface would allow students to petition grades and request instructor comment I imagine using this in large university classes where it would be too difficult to assign and grade numerous large writing assignments without peer review. In this system I get the best of both worlds. The students get quality writing assignments and detailed feedback from peers using a rubric and comments. If they are unhappy with their grade or would like an "expert" opinion on their writing, they have complete access to the instructor's feedback. I use this on assignments where there are no real right answers, it is just graded on completeness and polish. I envision a day where I create a MOOC with thousands of students in it, all starting and finishing the class at different times, having a rich and engaging experience that would be impossible otherwise.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Manual Allocation set ahead of time?
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there any plan to make a feature that will allow you setup manual allocations before the students submit their initial papers? Not really. The Workshop has been designed so that the assessment allocation is a relation between a reviewer and a submission, not between two users. I can see two possible approaches to your use case though. First, try to use the scheduled allocation combined with the automatic assessment phase switch. Set the submission deadline at Sunday 6 pm, let submissions allocated randomly by the scheduled allocator and let the Workshop to be switched to the assessment phase automatically. That way, the teacher does not need to be involved and students can spend their Sunday evening by doing assessments. The other option would be a custom allocation plugin that would have to be developed. The teacher would preset required allocations in advance and then, the allocator would try to actually assign them, if possible (i.e. if the submission actually exists). So it would work similarly to the scheduled allocation method, but using the predefined relations between authors and reviewers. Obviously, the first alternative can be used immediately, the second one requires custom development.

These calculations happen in clusters. In that mean that every final grade for submission is calculated from all reviews/assessments for the given submission (so if a submission was assessed by 5 reviewers, these 5 assessments form the final grade for that submission). every reviewer's final grading grade is calculated as a mean of all individual grading grades that the reviewer got. So, if Alice's submission was peer-assessed by Barbara, Cindy and Dona and Alan's submission was peer-assessed by Barbara, Charles and Dan, then Barbara's grading grade is calculated as a mean of two grading grades (because she did two reviews). The first of these grades is calculated by comparing Barbara's assessment with Cindy's and Dona's one. The particular detailed values (like average of received assessment for a single aspect) are not displayed.

ResponsesInList.Title: New grading evaluation method available - Participation credit
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi! I am happy to announce that the "Participation credit" subplugin has been just approved and published in the Moodle add-ons directory. This simple grading evaluation method gives credit to peer-reviewers just for their participation in the activity without comparing their assessment with the others. There are three modes of how grades for assessment are calculated by this method. All or nothing - The reviewer must assess all allocated submissions in order to obtain the maximum grade; otherwise they receive a grade of zero. Proportional - The grade obtained is proportional to the number of assessments. If all allocated submissions are assessed, the reviewer will obtain the maximum grade; if half of the allocated submissions are assessed, the reviewer will obtain 50% of the maximum grade. At least one - The reviewer must assess at least one allocated submission in order to obtain the maximum grade. See MDL-37603 and https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=workshopeval_credit

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: question about "late submitters"
ResponsesInList.Text: Once the workshop is in the Assessment phase, noone can submit any more. Unless you allow "Late submissions". In that case, those two students who have not submitted yet have a chance to submit their work even in the Assessment phase. Note in this case they have just one chance to press the "Submit" button. Once they do, they can't edit the submission any more. This feature was introduced exactly for this case so that the whole class does not need to wait for a couple of peers. Note there is no need to switch the workshop back to the Submission phase to be able to allocate submissions. You can allocate submissions any time (even though the planner tool suggests to do it at the end of the submission phase). There should be no issue with missing submissions and/or missing assessments during the Grading evaluation phase. The evaluator just uses actual assessments that are available. If there is a submission left that was not assessed, there is no grade for it calculated. If there is a reviewer who did not actually assess anything, no grade for assessment is calculated to them. It's up to the teacher to interpret the situation (eg set the grade manually to zero, exclude the activity for the student in the Gradebook etc.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: question about "late submitters"

Grades are written into the course gradebook when and only when the workshop is being closed (i.e. the phase is being changed to "Closed"). It is expected that the teacher uses the grading evaluation phase iteratively until their happy with the result. And that is why students do not have access to their grades until the workshop is closed. Also note, to use the "late submissions" feature, you do not actually need to switch the workshop back to the submission phase.

ResponsesInList.Title: Understanding grading evaluation algorithm in peer review Workshop module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, In my institution, several professors are enthousiastic while using the peer review worshop module. We find the possibilities of this module very impressive especifically the possibility to grade the grading process. We had a search about the grading algorithms because we wanna give explanations about it to students. We wanna use the accumulative evaluation that is described by the following formula : http://docs.moodle.org/dev/Workshop_2.0_specification#Accumulative In this formula, the grade is computed based on a ratio composed of - the grade given by the student for one criteria as numerator; - the maximum grade given by all students for that criteria as denominator. We think such ratio will encourage students to give high scores (while giving 100% to all peers ensures them to have 100% as evaluators). Intuitively, we would prefer de denominator to be the mean or median grade among all students given grades. What do you think about it ? Is there a scientific justification for the choice of the maximum value ? Are there other options for this formula based on scientific argumentation ? Finally, if we wanna tune the formula, in which file do we have to make the change ? Thanks in advance for answer, Zabelle

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Understanding grading evaluation algorithm in peer review Workshop module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Isabelle I am afraid there are several different concepts mixed up in your post. Firstly, the Accumulative grading strategy (with up-to-date docs available at http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/Workshop_grading_strategies#Accumulative_grading_strategy ) determines how the grade for submission is calculated. It has nothing to do with the grade for assessment. The formula describes how the grade for submission is calculated from the filled assessment form. It is a standard formula for weighted mean. The denominator is the sum of weights of all aspects in the form (or, if they all have the same weight equal to 1, their count), not a maximum grade given by all students, as you say. Also, I can't agree with your conclusion that students are encouraged to give high scores. The grading evaluation method "Comparison with the best assessment" (documented at http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/Using_Workshop#Grade_for_assessment ) gives high grade for those assessments that are closer to a "common sense" which itself is determined as the mean of all received assessments. In any case, you are free to implement your own grading evaluation method in as a subplugin and use it in your courses. The Moodle plugins directory already contains one such alternative. For the reference, let me point you to another thread in this forum where the calculation of grades for assessments was discussed.

ResponsesInList.Text: In Workshop, I have several students who correctly gave low scores to other students with poor work. Mostly, I had each student grade three other students, due to information from hours, days, weeks and months of searching in Moodle, eventually to find that's what Moodle demands in order to calculate an assessment grade. So, within each correct student's set of co-graders, the other two graders graded higher, but not as well. ResponsesInList.Text: It appears that scheduled allocation has been disabled when I have set up my workshop examples – is there something that needs to be selected in the initial setup of the workshop in order to enable scheduled allocation? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Workshop - Scheduled allocation
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, these two features (automatic switching from the submission to the assessment phase and scheduled allocation) are independent. Each one doing just its job: If automatic phase switching is enabled then the Workshop will switch to the assessment phase automatically after the submission deadline. Just that. If the scheduled allocation is explicitly enabled at the Scheduled allocation method page then it will automatically allocate submissions for assessment after the submission deadline. Just that. So yes, you can set automatic switching only. But then all what happens is that you would find the Workshop in the assessment phase with no submissions allocated. And vice versa. You can enable just the scheduled allocator - so you would find the Workshop still in the submission phase but with submissions allocated. Apparently, using the combination of both features is what you want to do in 99% of cases. Still we follow the general principle "do one thing and do it well" when developing subplugins for Workshop so that's why it is done as it is now. HTH

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Understanding accumulative grading
ResponsesInList.Text: This is not a bug. As it has been described in the docs as well as answered in forums, it's important to realize that in the Accumulative strategy, the actual maximum grade for each aspect does not influence its weight. So both aspects in your setup have the same weight (as both have it set to "1"). The final grade is calculated as an arithmetic mean of them. For example in the first assessment, given grades for aspect 1 and aspect 2 are 4/4 and 5/6, respectively. The total grade is then calculated as (4/4 + 5/6)/2 = 0.91666 which is then correctly displayed as 9.17 of 10.00. If you expected it being counted as (4 + 5)/(4 + 6) then you need to use the Rubric strategy (displayed in the grid or list layout of your choice). See http://docs.moodle.org/25/en/Workshop_grading_strategies for more details.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can individuals peer assess group uploads

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Submission Phase Expects all users from school, not course
ResponsesInList.Text: Joe, I think that this situation may be the result a common misconception by new moodle system admins. It's tempting to configure Moodle to emulate the roles that individuals have in the school. So a teacher logs in and gets the teacher role and a student the student role, right? But Moodle does not (and cannot) work that way. A Moodle 'teacher' is a user with the 'editingteacher' role within a course -- that user may be a Teacher in the school or she may in fact be a student depending upon circumstances. So once you as a user click on a course your role changes to the role which is assigned to you in that course (teacher, student or whatever). Thus there needs to be a 'neutral' role for any user account (apart from the moodle administrator) before a user enters a course. This role is called 'Authenticated User' and in 99% of all cases should be the default role in the Moodle system. Here's what the Roles Settings documentation says: Default role for all users The default role for all users should normally be set to Authenticated user . If it is set to Student then the result is that all students are enrolled on all courses. Note: The default role for all users should never be set to Guest . Once this has been set site-wide (and the doc link above gives details of how to do this) all your student enrollment problems will go away. It's a bit mind bending at first but as you play with roles you'll find that they are marvellously flexible. Clear as mud? Mark

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assessment form : Rubric
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark how to add an extra level to each Define the first four levels first. Then click the "Save and continue editing" button at the bottom of the form. The page will reload providing two more slots for additional levels. separate weights to apply to different criteria Multiple the grades for each level (those numbers in the drop down menus) with the required weight. ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mark, and welcome back to the Workshop users world I believe you will be able to use the Workshop module for your use case. ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jodi Firstly, you have decide what is more important for you - to have fixed number of assessments per submission or fixed number of assessment per reviewer. The allocator tries hard to produce balanced results but that is not always possible. As Leon suggests, if it is more important for you to have the same amount of work for each student, you may wish to prefer fixed number per reviewer (but then, some submissions may get assessed three times and some just once, for example). It really depends on whether you prefer equal workload for your students or equal amount of feedback per submission. Also note that the group mode affects this. In Visible groups mode, the allocator tries to pick reviewers from as many groups as possible. And that is probably why you get these results if the number of members are not equal across groups. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How do assessment grades work?
ResponsesInList.Text: The fact that two assessments led to the same grade does not necessarily mean they were similar to each other. Therefore the evaluation plugin compares individual criteria rather than the final grade. See https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=153268#p670406 for more details. Also note that it is actually student 4 who got the full mark as well - I would expect that their assessment is the same as yours and therefore they get 50 too. Then student 6 will have a slightly different one, still giving them 49. And so on. Look at the assessment by student 1 in more details. You should realize that even their assessment led to the grade 26 (compared to the grade 21 based on your assessment), it will be probably very different from yours when it comes to comparing individual aspects (dimensions) of the submission. Please keep us informed about your analysis.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Data Analysis Workshop?
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, even Workshop in Moodle 2.x does not support exporting data yet. The tricky part is the format of the output data. I agree we must be able to produce them somehow so they can be post-processed statistically. However, we must provide a general solution for all types of the grading forms in the Workshop. What I was thinking about was a unified format that would output the filled grading forms data as normalized values. What all grading forms have in common (regardless whether it is Rubric, Accumulative or whatever) is that they all consists of a set of assessment dimensions. The filled assessment is internally converted to a value from 0 to 100%. We could generate such report. So while data for the filled rubric would contain columns with values like 0.00, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 or 1.00 (in case of a rubric with 5 columns), the Number of errors (Error banded in 1.x) would produce just one column with either 0.00 or 1.00 - depending on what the reviewer (grader) said.

ResponsesInList.Title: Workshop 2.0 Gradebook integration
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a request for your comments on a proposal to change how Workshop integrates into the course Gradebook. In the current version, the calculated grade for submission and grade for assessment are summarized and pushed as a single grade into the gradebook (well, it does not work due to a reported bug at the moment, but it does not matter now). Since the time the Workshop appeared, the course Gradebook was improved in many ways. One of its not very well known features is that a module instance can actually push more than one grade items into the gradebook. As far as I know, no module uses this feature (if we do not count outcomes). I propose a change in the behaviour so that workshop publish both grade for submission and grade for assessment as separated grade items in the gradebook (leading to two columns in the report). Such a solution has some significant pros: teachers can choose their own way on how to deal with these two workshop grades - for example, the grade for assessment can be considered as extra credit teachers can calculate things like an average grade for submission across all workshop in the course etc. teachers can easily deal with missing grades in individual cases - it est they can exclude the low grade for submission for a student who was ill and joined the Workshop workflow later in the assessment phase only. The Gradebook already has the logic implemented. The only con I can see at the moment is, if a teacher requires the legacy behaviour (the workshop total grade = grade for submission + grade for assessment), an extra step is needed: a special category in the gradebook must be created containing the two workshop grades, with an aggregation method set to Sum of grades (see the attached screenshot). I plan to release the first testable version of the workshop next week. Your early comments are welcome therefore d.

ResponsesInList.Title: Global Settings

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global Settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry Vernellia, please elaborate. What setting is not available to you when you set up a workshop? The main Workshop setting form is independent on the current phase so you should have all settings available there. There is intentionally no way how to override the aggregated grade for assessment within the workshop. What you can do is to override a partial grade for a single assessment. But the overall grade for assessments is calculated as a mean of grades for all given assessments. Alternatively, you can override the grade in the course Gradebook once the grades are pushed there. There is no way how to publish all assessments at once at the moment. Because Workshop was considered as an advanced variant of the Assignment module, the submission is considered to be private. The publishing feature is there so the teacher can publish the exemplary work by individual students. If you want all submissions to be published, you may use some another module (like a Database or Forum) for submitting and use Workshop for the peer-assessment only (instead of providing full text, your student would submit just a link to their work submitted elsewhere at a public place). p.s. please create separate discussion thread per each issue, it will help to keep track of it. Thanks in advance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global Settings
ResponsesInList.Text: The settings that are missing from the main setting Allocation settings Random Allocation Number Participants can assess without having submitted anything Grading method assessment Comparison with the best assessment

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global Settings
ResponsesInList.Text: Well, this is intentional. While Workshop 1.9 was a monolithic module, Workshop 2.0 architecture extensively uses subplugins. That means that Allocators and Grading evaluators are independent components that are just plugged-in to the Workshop. It allows to implements custom add-ons to standard Workshop features. For example, if someone needs a sophisticated way how to allocate submissions according to overall students' performance so that excellent students assess only other excellent students while poor students assess other students etc, they ccan develop their own allocation subplugin. It is like in the Quiz - when editing the Quiz settings, you do not define the questions because questions are independent on the Quiz.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global Settings
ResponsesInList.Text: I can understand wanting to make the workshop capability have as much flexibility as possible. But not being able to make all the choices when the workshop is first set up makes doing workshops more time consuming. Is there any way that you could select the random allocation and the number of allocation at the time, weight of faculty assessments and allocation of submissions to faculty member? For instance, could we go into the plugin and set those options at when we set up the workshop?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global Settings
ResponsesInList.Text: This clearly depends on how you use workshop. I can see that you would prefer legacy behaviour when everything is set and defined in advance and then workshop just runs without much teacher's input needed. But the new version was developed so that these tools are interactive and can be combined in many ways. For example, you can let Random allocator do some initial random assignments and tweak it using the Manual allocation tool. Or vice versa, define several required allocations (like a teacher really wants to assess John's and Mary's submissions personally) and let all other being allocated randomly. Or, when the grades for assessment are calculated, the teacher is expected to iteratively play with the setting, changing the weights, overriding the calculated values etc. until they are happy with the overall result. From this point of view, it is very natural to have the setting form available just in time when they are needed and not before.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Global Settings

By making all the settings -- just in time when they are needed is of course one natural option Of course, for a very busy teacher, with a large class and a number responsibilities beside minding workshop -- I need the ability to make those choices when I set up the workshop. Delaying the time is not natural -- but forces me and others to be tied to managing the software. I am suggesting that in the interest of flexibility and useability -- if it can be done -- than it ought to be done.

Hi Trudy, I am the one who wrote the part of the code that makes you worry. Apparently, your database contains some invalid data that are not supposed to be there. In details, there are some orphaned grade records in your 1.9 workshop table that are not linked with any assessment. You can fix it by direct access to your database only. You should fix your database before you start the upgrade to 2.0. Of course, I assume it is still your test site and you have full backup of your production environment. Firstly, lauch your favourite MySQL client and run 
```text
mysql> SELECT * FROM mdl_workshop_grades WHERE assessmentid IS NULL;
```
 That will probably give you some results - those orphaned grades without the assessment. You can delete them with 
```text
mysql> DELETE FROM mdl_workshop_grades WHERE assessmentid IS NULL;
```
 That should not influence your workshops as the orphaned grades are not owned by any user.

Hi Trudy, my suspicion was correct though the SQL above to test was not. I have analysed your database and there are inconsistencies between workshop_grades and workshop_assessments tables. One of your assessment record was somehow removed but the linked grades remained and that threw the upgrade record. To find those orphaned grades record you can use 
```text
SELECT g.id, g.assessmentid
FROM mdl_workshop_grades g
LEFT JOIN mdl_workshop_assessments a ON g.assessmentid = a.id
WHERE a.id IS NULL;
```
 and it will give you eight grade records that refer to a non-existing assessment. I am going to patch the upgrade code in workshop so that it handles this case as well. So either you can remove those grades manually or wait for tomorrow's Moodle 2.0 build to test again with. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is my understanding of the grade calculation correct?
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes Vernellia, this is correct. I would personally just use higher weight of the teacher's assessment so that it helps workshop to calculate the final given grade more accurately.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is my understanding of the grade calculation correct?
ResponsesInList.Text: Has this changed for Moodle 2.0 workshops? I have looked through the materials and tried to step through a sample workshop. I find the screens where I can review comments and scores from peer raters, and do an over-ride with note. I'm presuming that it's here I'd need to work to copy and paste student comments about peers since I don't think those are emailed. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is my understanding of the grade calculation correct?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Steve. There is no conceptual difference between peer assessment and faculty assessment in 2.0. Every role with the permission to submit can do so. Such a submission then has to be allocated for an assessment (aka review) and a weight of that assessment can be set. So if you want a submission be assessed by some user, either allocate the submission to them or give them permission to allocate submissions so they can assess them themselves (if users can allocate submissions, they could allocate any submission to themselves so effectively they are able to assess any submission they select).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is my understanding of the grade calculation correct?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the clarification. It's my understanding then that the faculty member shouldn't try to design a situation where their assessment is weighted with those of peer reviewers. Rather it seems far simpler to allow student peers to evaluate, and then as faculty to review and over-ride as judged appropriate with comment. This way the faculty member doesn't have to submit an essay or post of the assignment itself and then manually over-ride random allocations to be qualified as a rater for each class member. I can surely live with that! I wonder if there would ever be a way of rigging the system up to allow a manager or faculty member to 'submit' on behalf of students. I'm just thinking how one could use this tool for peer assessment of performance. In this case the trigger is not an essay or post, but something more along the lines of evaluating the person's contribution. If some stock words could comprise the submission, then assessment scales could be devised (support, teamwork, leadership,etc.) for offline performance assessment with all the virtues of considering the peer rating as well as the pattern of ratings.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Is my understanding of the grade calculation correct?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Steve, faculty members do not need to submit their own work to be able to assess students' submissions. In Workshop 2.0, the teacher can assign herself as a reviewer of a work. I can even imagine a new allocation method (that is a third card at the Allocation page) that randomly picks N given submissions and allocates them to the current user (or any other given user). This way, workshop with 50 students could run in a classic peer-review mode and the teacher could just randomly pick 5 or 7 submissions to check. Submitting on behalf students is possible with the standard "login as" feature. However I think that the teacher can just ask all students to simply upload a very short information (like their team name or even their own name or so) just to register them in the workshop. And yes - you are right - since then, you can actually assess anything, not only the submission itself.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: delayed emails from workshop module
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Caryl, I may have a suspicion what is going on here. In Workshop 1.x, whenever a submission is allocated to be reviewed by a peer (which is done automatically and nobody can control that much), a new assessment record is created in the database and its timecreated flag is set one year into the future to signalize that this assessment has not been completed yet by the peer. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Workshop module
ResponsesInList.Text: I'll move this to the Workshop forum for David to respond.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Workshop module
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Michael, your request makes perfect sense and using Workshop 2.0 in such situation was one of the use cases I had when designing it. The checkbox "Use peer-assessment" is available as a fresh new feature but it is not taken into account too much yet. I mean - user interface does not depend on it (yet) so some irrelevant features (like the overriding you mentioned or the columns in the workshop grades report) are still visible. The plan is that Workshop without peer-assessment feature would behave similarly to the Assignment module while still offering the advanced grading methods like rubrics. The development was focused on mainstream usage of Workshop though so this will not happen in 2.0, sorry. But, I am pretty sure you can use Workshop in 2.0 for your situation:
* Just set the maximum grade for assessment to zero
* Set the course gradebook so that it ignores and hides workshop grade for assessment item from your students completely
* Skip submission allocation - you as the teacher can assess all submissions by default and they are allocated to you automatically once you press the "Assess" button, without the need to use allocator.
* Do not fill instructions for assessments so they are not displayed to your students The reason why I want to wait for wider feedback from the community before I start hiding various bits of UI is that your situation is just one of use cases we must count with. Imagine for example there are hundreds of submissions in the workshop and you have some assistants (non-editing teachers, mentors etc) that help you with assessing. In this case it is not clean peer assessment as normal students just submit their work (authors) while the other group of users (reviewers) assess them. The master teacher could want to calculate grades for assessments for the assistants to see how relevant their assessment is. In this case, you still want to see peer-assessment features (for example the master teacher wants to override the grade given by their assistants) even if students do not go through peer-assessment phase. Sure, you will not probably give feedback to yourself at the bottom of the assessment form. But you may want to use the field for your own notes maybe? And maybe you can run into situation when you do not agree with the grade calculated by the rubric and will want to modify it a bit - for example because the assessed student has some disabilities you as the human can respect while the blindly objective rubric can not. Summary: workshop should be flexible enough for your need if you can live with the fact you may be offered some options you do not want to use at the given scenario. Hope this explains the reasons a bit - looking forward for your comments and thoughts!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Assessment Grade Not Average
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Vernellia In your workshop setting, you have apparently set "Number of Assessments of Student Submissions" to 5. Workshop 1.9 uses this number when calculating the final grade for assessments, not the real number of assessments. The missing assessments are considered as having the assessment grade 0. So, in case of the first row, the final assessment grade is calculated as (40+50+27+40)/5 In Workshop 2.0, this grade is correctly calculated as weighted mean from real grades only.

ResponsesInList.Title: Peer assessment requirements
ResponsesInList.Text: Am I correct in my understanding that the following conditions need to be correctly configured in order for students to see each others submissions (for peer assessment): 1. The "Start of assessments" date/time must come after the "End of submissions" date/time. In other words, submissions must be closed before peer assessment can begin. 2. The "Start of assessments" date/time must be at least 30 minutes after the "End of submissions" date/time. 3. The "Number of Assessments of Student Submissions" must be greater than 0.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Peer assessment requirements
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Greg, in Moodle 1.9, the "Start of assessment" can actually comes before the "End of submissions". The original idea was that students do not need to wait for others to finish their submission. You may want to increase the overall allocation to allow early-submitting students to start assessing. In Moodle 2.0, submission phase and assessment phase can't overlap any more to prevent some weird situations. So the setting you described in 2. would work for you best and it is closest to this future behaviour.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Peer assessment requirements
ResponsesInList.Text: Not being able to overlap simplifies the process, but would seem to complicate things in classes where there's stragglers and irregular submitters, like my elementary class.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Peer assessment requirements
ResponsesInList.Text: Dan, yes, I kept this in mind. There will be a way to allow late submitters to send their work even after regular submission phase. In such case, no other modifications will be allowed after the submission form is saved. Note that in workshop 2.0, even students without their own submission can still participate in the peer assessment. They just do not receive any grade for submission so you can, for example, exclude it from grading in the course gradebook. d.

ResponsesInList.Title: Editing assessment form - "Number of errors" grading strategy
ResponsesInList.Text: This is how teachers define the assessment form, when the Workshop uses "Number of errors" grading strategy (currently known as "Error banded"). The teacher defines a set of "assertions", ie propositions that may be evaluated and answered with "Yes/Good/Correct" or "No/Bad/Error". The grade for submission is based on the number of bad/error/missing aspects of the submitted work. The assertions can be weighted. The assertion with a weight X is calculated X-times when mapping the number of errors to a grade.

ResponsesInList.Title: Workshop planner tool
ResponsesInList.Text: The new version introduces a new user interface element called Workshop planner. Basically it displays all workshop phases (stages) and highlights the current phase. For every phase, a list of tasks the user is expected to do is provided. So the Workshop planner quickly informs both workshop participants (students) and moderators (teachers) what they are expected to do right now. The planner populates tasks dynamically for every user to provide relevant and up-to-date information about the current state of the whole activity. Using the planner, moderators (teachers) shall easily recognize the progress of participants' work and get a quick overview of how many of them have submitted their work, finished their reviews etc. From the technical point of view, the tool uses the new HTML output machinery. Thanks to that, advanced themers can not only tweak how the planner is CSS-styled but also to change the HTML output completely . See the attached picture for an example of what the planner may display to the Workshop moderator during the Submission phase.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Workshop Case Study
ResponsesInList.Text: I read your case study with interest, as Workshop is my favorite Moodle activity. I have a few comments. (1) An important factor seems to be missing in your "alternative approach": teacher assessment. Teacher assessment is essential to a workshop. Students are graded on the QUALITY of their assessments, where quality is a function of the difference between the teacher's assessment and the student's assessment. The teacher's assessment is the normative force that draws participants toward a consensus. (2) I do not see how students can begin work without having at least seen the assessment elements. The purpose of the "assess one or more examples provided by the teacher" phase of Workshop (which you omit) is to familiarize students with the assessment elements by having them make one or more practice assessments BEFORE they begin their own work. It's like calibrating a laboratory instrument before you start making measurements. There is no place for subjectivity in a Workshop (it's at the opposite end of the spectrum from Blog ). Workshop is the best tool in Moodle for helping students develop a critical eye toward their own and others' work.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Workshop Case Study
